Title: Development of E-Learning for social communities using the content management system to support information management activities (A case study approach)
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat  11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kurniawan, Y., Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat  11480, Indonesia; Chandra, A.N., Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat  11480, Indonesia; Johan, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat  11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper aims to design a model of e-learning for social community, it can be developed into a website using content management system for information management, so it can facilitate social communities to exchange information, online learning, search and manage data, set the life cycle and personalize the website, so it can produce information more accurate, timely, relevant, reliable and ultimately improve the quality of information from social communities. Development activities in this research: starting with the analysis, design and implementing e-Learning Application Model for Social Community. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Content management system; E-Learning; Social communities
References: Black, D., Dreams of Pure Sociology (2000) Sociological Theory, 18, p. 343; Lee, H., Choi, B., (2003) Journal of Management Information Systems, 20, p. 179; Tsai, M.T., Lee, K.W., (2006) Journal of Knowledge Management, 10, p. 57; Bhatt, G., (2000) Journal of Knowledge Management, 4, p. 15; Murray, P., Donegan, K., (2003) The Learning Organization, 10, p. 51; Horton, W., (2012) E-Learning by Design, , Pfeiffer, San Francisco; Gundry, J., (2003), http://www.knowab.co.uk/elflexible.html, SeptemberHow Flexible is E-Learning? Retrieved from Knowledge Ability; Satzinger, J.W., Jackson, R.B., Burd, S.D., (2008) Systems Analysis and Design in a Changing World, , 5th edn., Cengage Learning, Boston
Correspondence Address: Kurniawan, Y.; Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan No 9, Indonesia

Title: A model of business intelligence systems for school: A case study (perception applications and benefits)
Affiliations: Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Chandra, A.N., Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kurniawan, Y., Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Usually the purpose with business intelligence is to increase the profit, through capturing, storing, sharing, and utilizing knowledge in an innovative way. Are the concepts of business intelligence applicable to schools? If that is the case, then the primary and secondary education sectors should be replete with examples of institutions that leverage business intelligence to achieve operational excellence. This paper discusses the need for business intelligence from the perspectives of teachers in academic services, perceptions of application and benefits. However, although some examples exist, they are the exception rather than the rule. We believe there is tremendous value to school institutions that develop initiatives to achieve business objectives. The business intelligence can be classified as support for teaching staff decision making. The conclusion is that business intelligence could be used in schools, facilitating the business intelligence within the organization for academic services. © Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht 2015.
Index Keywords: Applications; Competitive intelligence; Decision making; Education; Societies and institutions; Teaching; Ubiquitous computing; Wireless sensor networks; Benefit; Business intelligence systems; Business objectives; Operational excellence; Primary and secondary education; School; Teaching staff; Information analysis
References: Fact Gap Fuels ERP Investments and Invites Printer Vendors to Ride the Wave, , http://www.techexchange.com/thelibrary/RideTheWave.html; Marchand, D.A., Kettinger, W.J., Rollins, J.D., (2002) Information Orientation: The Link to Business Performance, , Oxford University Press, Oxford; Stackowiak, R., Rayman, J., Greenwald, R., (2007) Oracle Data Warehousing and Business Intelligence Solutions, , Wiley Publishing, Indianapolis; Zeng, L., Xu, L., Shi, Z., Wang, M., Wu, W., Techniques, process, and enterprise solutions of business intelligence (2007) IEEE Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics, 6, p. 4722. , Taipei, Taiwan, 8-11 Oct 2006; Arnott, D., Pervan, G., A critical analysis of decision support systems research (2005) J Inf Technol, 20 (2), pp. 67-87; Williams, S., Williams, N., (2007) The Profit Impact of Business Intelligence, , Morgan Kaufmann, San Francisco; Wang, Z., (2005) Business Intelligence, , DrMaster Culture Limited Company, Taipei; Goebel, M., Le, G., (1999) A Survey of Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery Software Tools, 1 (1). , ACM, New York; Albert, S., Knowledge management: Living up to the hope (1998) Midrange Syst, 11 (13), p. 52; Malhotra, Y., From information management to knowledge management: Beyond hi-tech hidebound systems (2000) Knowledge Management, pp. 37-62. , In: Srikantaiah TK, Koenig MED, Information Today, Medford; Chamoni, P., Gluchowski, P., Integration trends in business intelligence systems—an empirical study based on the business intelligence maturity model (2004) Wirtschaftsinformatik, 46 (2), pp. 119-128; Williams, S., Delivering strategic business value (2004) Strateg Finance, 86 (2), pp. 40-48; Najjar, L., (2002) The Impact of Information Quality and Ergonomics on Service Quality in the Banking Industry, , University of Nebraska, Lincoln; Salaun, Y., Flores, K., Information quality: Meeting the needs of the consumer (2001) Int J Inf Manage, 21 (1), pp. 21-37
